title: The Beloved and the Shulamite
shortSummary: Song of Solomon Chapter 6 explores the mutual love and admiration between the beloved and the Shulamite woman, highlighting their unique and exclusive relationship amidst many others. The chapter uses rich poetic imagery to express the beauty, desire, and spiritual intimacy shared between them, emphasizing the theme of devoted love.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, traditionally attributed to Solomon's reign

keyCharacters.name: The Shulamite Woman
keyCharacters.description: The female protagonist who expresses longing and affection for her beloved, representing the bride in this poetic love dialogue.

keyCharacters.name: The Beloved
keyCharacters.description: The male figure, often understood as Solomon or a shepherd, who is the object of the Shulamite's love and admiration.

keyCharacters.name: The Daughters of Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: A chorus or group of women who observe and comment on the love between the Shulamite and her beloved, encouraging and praising their relationship.

definitions.definition: A term referring to the woman from Shulem or Shunem, symbolizing purity and beloved status in the poem.
An ancient city in Israel, used here as a metaphor for beauty and desirability.
Likely a noble or chariot leader; the term is used metaphorically to describe swift and powerful movement.
Women who lived with a man but had lower status than a wife; mentioned to contrast the Shulamite's unique position.

outline.heading: The Search for the Beloved
outline.description: The daughters of Jerusalem inquire about the whereabouts of the beloved, and the Shulamite responds with tender imagery of her beloved in his garden, emphasizing their intimate bond.

outline.heading: Praise of the Shulamite's Beauty
outline.description: The beloved extols the Shulamite's physical beauty using vivid and symbolic comparisons, highlighting her captivating and overwhelming presence.

outline.heading: The Unique Beloved Among Many
outline.description: The Shulamite is distinguished from many queens, concubines, and virgins as the one true and undefiled beloved, underscoring exclusivity and divine favor.

outline.heading: The Shulamite's Radiant Appearance
outline.description: A rhetorical question praises the Shulamite's radiant and majestic appearance, likening her to celestial bodies and a formidable army.

outline.heading: The Beloved's Visit to the Garden
outline.description: The beloved describes going down to the garden to see the flourishing fruits, symbolizing care and attentiveness in the relationship, followed by a metaphor of swift movement.

outline.heading: Call for the Shulamite's Return
outline.description: The daughters of Jerusalem urge the Shulamite to return so they may behold her beauty, portraying her as a powerful and awe-inspiring presence.

application: Cherish and honor the unique and exclusive love God calls us to in marriage, reflecting Christ's love for the Church.
Recognize the beauty and worth God imparts to His people, encouraging believers to see themselves as beloved and chosen.
Pursue spiritual intimacy with Christ through prayer and devotion, just as the Shulamite and her beloved share deep fellowship.
Encourage and support fellow believers in their walk of faith, much like the daughters of Jerusalem who uplift and celebrate love.

keyVerses.text: I am my beloved's, and my beloved is mine: he feedeth among the lilies.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the mutual belonging and intimate relationship between the lovers, symbolizing the deep union between Christ and His Church.

keyVerses.text: My dove, my undefiled is but one; she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her. The daughters saw her, and blessed her; yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the Shulamite's uniqueness and purity, affirming the value of faithfulness and God's special calling on His people.

keyVerses.text: Who is she that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the sun, and terrible as an army with banners?
keyVerses.significance: This poetic description emphasizes the Shulamite's radiant beauty and strength, reflecting the glory and majesty bestowed by God.
